image.altText: legs of a young person in jeans in a dark stairwell.

props.synopsis: The SA opposition says the state is in the grip of a "youth crime crisis", and while the state's police chief has denied the situation is "worse than it has ever been", the government has ruled out raising the age of criminal responsibility.

title.children: Is SA facing a 'youth crime crisis', and how should it manage young offenders?

image.altText: Henry Thornton of South Australia celebrates, raising his arms and extending his index fingers

props.synopsis: South Australia's triumphant cricketers are setting their sights on a historic double, after winning the one-day competition for the first time in 13 years.

title.children: South Australia end 13-year drought with One Day Cup triumph

image.altText: Australian players around their captain, who is lifting a trophy, as confetti falls

props.synopsis: The Young Socceroos have battled their way to glory in the Under-20 Asian Cup, beating Saudi Arabia in a penalty shootout in the final on a breakthrough day for Australian soccer.

title.children: Young Socceroos make history with first Asian Cup triumph

image.altText: Close up image of lamb and other meat in a cabinet at a butcher

props.synopsis: While many meat eaters have opted for local butchers over supermarkets in recent years, some butchers say they are finding it tough to find and retain qualified staff and apprentices.

title.children: Local butchers bounce back, but staffing is a challenge

image.altText: Beaumont children photo

props.synopsis: A seven-day search for the Beaumont children, who went missing from Glenelg Beach in 1966, has concluded after "almost 10,000 tonnes" of soil was dug up as part of the "biggest clandestine grave dig in the world".

title.children: 'We can walk away satisfied': Search for Beaumont children concludes

image.altText: A man with grey hair and a grey goatee smiling while leaning back in a lounge chair.

props.synopsis: An experienced South Australian snake catcher has spent a week in hospital after being bitten by a lice-infested snake he was treating with a bath.

title.children: One lousy bath leaves snake catcher in hot water

image.altText: Men working to construct a large transmission line tower, land dotted with shrubs, blue sky.

props.synopsis: Cost estimates for Australia's largest energy transmission project have blown out by almost 75 per cent, sparking fears of higher power bills.

title.children: Fears $1.5 billion transmission line cost blowout will increase bills

image.altText: A building at Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: The SA government had been pursuing GFG Alliance over unpaid royalties since the beginning of last year — and made repeated threats to suspend the company's mining permits, according to documents obtained under Freedom of Information.

title.children: SA government had been chasing GFG Alliance over debts since early 2024

image.altText: Rhoda Roberts holding on to a boxing bag.

props.synopsis: A new stage show at this year's Adelaide Festival shines a light on the struggles that one of Australia's first Indigenous Olympians faced both in and out of the boxing ring, and on his battle for securing recognition and respect inside his own country. Warning: This story contains the image and name of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: He was a trailblazer in the ring, now his battle is being celebrated on stage

image.altText: A court sketch of a man with glasses sitting in the dock

props.synopsis: A man who shot an unarmed trespasser four times at close range before burying him two metres underground inside a shed north of Adelaide in 2023 is found guilty of murder.

title.children: Man found guilty of murdering unarmed trespasser he buried in shed

image.altText: Shiraz grapes on the vine at the Kalleske winery in South Australia.

props.synopsis: Farmers in Australia's largest wine grape regions are calling on the federal government to implement a mandatory code of conduct immediately to stop a mass exodus of growers.

title.children: Wine grape growers demand safeguards for industry in 'crisis'

image.altText: Firefighters in the field.

props.synopsis: South Australians are warned to prepare for an extended high-risk bushfire season across several districts as hot, dry conditions show no signs of abating.

title.children: No end in sight to SA bushfire danger after record dry spell

image.altText: A kelpie collie dog, with brown fur in two shades and white patches sitting on couch next to blurred owner in background.

props.synopsis: Two-thirds of Australian households have a pet, but in some states body corporates can ban even home owners from keeping animals. With high-density housing on the rise, strata industry leaders and pet owners are advocating for change.

title.children: In four Australian jurisdictions, body corporates are allowed to ban pets

image.altText: A primary school-aged boy standing inside a room of a house and smiling.

props.synopsis: Police have arrested a 23-year-old man in South Australia after a 12-year-old Alice Springs boy, missing since Thursday, was found safe and well in Coober Pedy.

title.children: Missing 12-year-old Alice Springs boy found in Coober Pedy, man arrested

image.altText: A woman and man with serious expressions stand close together in front of a caravan park

props.synopsis: After rebuilding their Riverland caravan park in the wake of a devastating flood, Barbara and Geoff Calvert are facing a new challenge — surging insurance premiums.

title.children: South Australians deal with rising insurance premiums following floods and fires

image.altText: AFL player Zak Butters running and dropping the football, preparing to punt it away

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide vice-captain Zak Butters will be sidelined for at least six weeks after having knee surgery.

title.children: Power vice-captain to miss several matches following surgery

image.altText: A little corella looks down from a gum tree

props.synopsis: Kangaroo Island residents say their children are at risk of disease from little corella poo splashing across play equipment and school lunch areas, but the education department refuses to consider a cull.

title.children: 'Thousands and thousands' of little corellas causing big poo problem

image.altText: Stewart Johnston, standing in a crowd, frowns as he speaks to reporters.

props.synopsis: Stewart Johnston, who remained a high-profile advocate for reform in the aged care sector following the abuse scandal at Oakden, has been sentenced to just over a year in jail after earlier pleading guilty to a charge of knowingly possessing child exploitation material.

title.children: Oakden campaigner Stewart Johnston jailed for possessing child exploitation material

image.altText: overhead satellite photo of houses adjacent sand dunes

props.synopsis: A Tennyson resident says plans for a coastal walk from Grange to Tennyson reveal a 40-metre blockage in the dunes that link it to Stage One of the project.

title.children: Adelaide walkway plans show 'blockage' in beach suburb dunes

image.altText: Young woman wearing hijab covering her face in the crowd.

props.synopsis: Anger over slashed government budgets, poor quality of life, career stagnation and rampant official corruption is motivating many Indonesians to fantasise about "running away" from the country.

title.children: Young people fantasise about 'escaping' South-East Asia's largest economy

image.altText: Young smiling girl, braces wears blue tee with surf culture australia written, holds surfboard, house, white sand in background.

props.synopsis: Home Education Association says the number of people choosing to homeschool their children is growing. However, an academic warns it may not be for everyone.

title.children: Why do so many Australians homeschool their children?

image.altText: A man hunches over a reel-to-reel tape player.

props.synopsis: Samuel Beckett's plays challenged the norm in the mid-20th century, so it's fitting that a director who champions new writers should open the Adelaide Festival with his major work, Krapp's Last Tape.

title.children: Samuel Beckett an ongoing champion for new writing at Adelaide Festival

image.altText: Thanasi Kokkinakis gives thumbs up in a bed

props.synopsis: Thanasi Kokkinakis has undergone surgery to try to correct the "mental and physical torture" he was suffering through a long-standing pectoral injury.

title.children: Kokkinakis has surgery in bid to end 'mental and physical torture'

image.altText: Image shows a row of small white crosses in a field of grass with tress and blue skies in the background.

props.synopsis: Across the country, countless sets of human remains sit in storage. Families are hoping the creation of Australia's first independent forensic science service will help solve cases and return remains to where they belong

title.children: Independent DNA lab aims to solve mysteries of unidentified remains

image.altText: Australian Dollar coins and notes generic

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar sell-off suggests that while we may be slowly digging our way out of the cost-of-living crisis, global economic storm clouds are gathering.

title.children: The latest Australian dollar sell-off is a red flag for the economy

image.altText: Khaled Sabsabi, with dark hair pulled back and grey beard, stands against brown brick wall wearing dark shirt.

props.synopsis: The decision about Australia's Venice Biennale exhibition is political but it reveals a cycle in which flaws are found in institutions that should be at arm’s length from politics and leaves them too weak to do the job they were established for.

title.children: Art controversy reveals a trend that ultimately weakens institutions

image.altText: fire was set off in front of a building while protesters and police standing around the fire

props.synopsis: A protest in Athens has turned violent as hundreds of thousands of people rally across the country on the second-anniversary of Greece's deadliest-ever train crash.

title.children: Clashes erupt in Greece as hundreds of thousands protest deadly train crash

image.altText: A two-storey guard tower sits behind rows of barbed-wire fences running along the border between North Korea and South Korea.

props.synopsis: Sounding somewhere between a wailing ghost or howling wolves, strange and disconcerting noises drift over the border from North Korea into South Korea — sometimes all day.

title.children: On the Korean peninsula, eerie noises are driving people wild

image.altText: Image of a younger man with a hat and glasses in front of trees.

props.synopsis: The forced culling of millions of hens has led to egg shortages and rising prices across Australia.

title.children: No eggs on the shelves? One farmer lost 540,000 chooks overnight

image.altText: A view from above of a man sitting cross-legged on a prayer mat with a quran in front of him and his hands open.

props.synopsis: Ramadan is a sacred time for Muslims around the world. Here's how non-Muslims can learn more and share the celebration.

title.children: How to support your Muslim friends this Ramadan

image.altText: gene hackman and his wife betsy arakawa

props.synopsis: Hackman, his wife Betsy Arakawa and one of their three dogs were found dead by a maintenance worker who had arrived to do routine work at their Santa Fe home on Wednesday.

title.children: Mystery of Gene Hackman and wife's death deepens as police search house

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Trump sitting down

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump asks a journalist what he was referring to when he mentioned the acronym "AUKUS" during a White House press conference.

title.children: 'What does that mean?', Trump asks after question on AUKUS

image.altText: Ferrari driver Lewis Hamilton lowers himself into his F1 car, while it is in the garge being worked on

props.synopsis: Pre-season testing often leaves fans with more questions than answers, but what was observed over the past three days can provide some insight into the upcoming season. Here are five key takeaways from Formula 1's pre-season testing.

title.children: Ferrari is all in while others look to the future

image.altText: Bushrangers Andrew George Scott, also known as Captain Moonlite, and James Nesbitt

props.synopsis: In the late 1800s, two bushrangers are suspected to have been in a romantic relationship. Historians say their story is a "rare window" into 19th-century same-sex love.

title.children: Captain Moonlite and James Nesbitt a 'window' into 19th-century same-sex love
